title: Groups vs. Teams
content: A group is people together; a team shares purpose, interdependence, and accountability. Teams coordinate, not just coexist. In operations, groups fail under pressure—teams adapt. The difference is intentional design: shared goals, defined roles, mutual accountability, and collective commitment to outcomes.

mcq.question: Five workers share a workspace but work independently on unrelated tasks. Are they a team?

options.B: No—they lack interdependence and shared purpose

mcq.explanation: Teams require more than proximity. Without shared goals, interdependence, and mutual accountability, they're a group. Co-location isn't coordination.

openQuestions: What distinguishes your team from a mere collection of individuals?
Where have you seen groups fail where teams would have succeeded?
